body: Mirror Printing Office and Book Bindery begins printing the Weekly Mirror, an advertising sheet published by Jesse Yarnell, T.J. Caystile and S.J. Mathes.
title: The Weekly Mirror begins publication

body: Nathan Cole Jr. and Thomas Gardiner start the Los Angeles Daily Times, which is printed by the Mirror Printing Office. It is published daily except Mondays. A.W. Francisco, a longtime friend of Harrison Gray Otis, is a silent partner.
title: Los Angeles Daily Times begins publication

body: The Times-Mirror Co. is incorporated. Otis buys the holdings of Jesse Yarnell and A.W. Francisco; Col. H.H. Boyce buys the interest of S.J. Mathes.
title: Times-Mirror Co. is incorporated

body: Harry Chandler, son-in-law of publisher Harrison Gray Otis, becomes the second publisher of the Times following Harrison Otis' death. Chandler family heirs will run the paper and the Times Mirror Co. until it's sold to the Tribune Co. in 2000.
title: Harry Chandler becomes publisher following stepfather's death

body: The Los Angeles Times and Washington Post join forces to syndicate many of their stories to other newspaper outlets, including leading newspapers in the United States and Canada.
title: The LA Times-Washington Post News Service formed

body: The Times' circulation reaches more than 1.2 milion readers daily and 1.5 million readers on Sunday, more than The New York Times by about 200,000.
title: LA Times becomes the largest metro daily in the U.S.

body: The Times launches latimes.com. The website is derived from the former TimesLink service on the Prodigy network.
title: The Times launches latimes.com

body: The merger, approved by stockholders of both companies in June 2000, is finalized. The Tribune becomes the only media company with a television, newspaper and interactive combination in the top three markets: New York, Los Angeles and Chicago. The Times is owned by the Tribune Co.
title: Times-Mirror merges with Tribune Co.

body: The Times starts to move away from block-by-block coverage and refocuses its local and regional coverage on all of Southern Californians.
title: 14 Our Times editions cease publication

body: Disgusted with the rounds of staff cuts, Editor-in-Chief John Carroll leaves the Times. "The whole purpose of the cutting was to keep present management in their jobs for another year or two," he said, " which was not something frankly I could identify with." Managing editor Dean P. Baquet takes his place as the new editor-in-chief.
title: Editor-in-Chief John Carroll leaves

body: Editor-In-Chief Dean Baquet is forced to resign after he publicly defies orders by the Tribune to cut jobs. Shortly after, he's interviewed by PBS' "Frontline" program on his thoughts on the industry. Baquet is replaced by James O'Shea, managing editor of the Chicago Tribune.
title: Editor-in-Chief Dean Baquet resigns
caption: Los Angeles Times Editor In Chief Dean Baquet and reporter Sumi Khan attend The International Women's Media Foundation's 2005 Courage In Journalism Awards on November 2, 2005 in Beverly Hills, California.

body: Over a period of six years, the newspaper staff drops 200 employees, reducing its newsroom staff to a low of 940. The Times continues to have one of the largest newsrooms in the United States.
title: Newroom loses 200 positions in 6 years

body: Editor-in-chief James O'Shea leaves the Times after a dispute over newsroom cuts with publisher, David Hiller. O'Shea goes on to publish a tell-all bestseller on the Times-Tribune relationship titled "The Deal From Hell: How Moguls and Wall Street Plundered Great American Newspapers." He's succeeded in the editor spot by innovation editor Russ Stanton.
title: Editor-in-Chief James O'Shea resigns
caption: O'Shea on Bloomberg News talks about his tell-all book on the Tribune-Times merger

body: Tensions run high at the L.A. Times after about 150 editorial staff and 100 non-editorial employees are laid off. In order to stem costs, Sam Zell reduces the paper’s size by 15 percent. A sign hung from the paper's parking lot on July 25, 2008, reads "Zell Hell: Take Back The L.A. Times."
title: Tensions high as nearly 250 employees laid off
caption: A banner hanging from the historic Times building in downtown Los Angeles reads: "Zell Hell: Take back the Los Angeles Times." A website address on the bottom directed the curious to the mysterious protest site by an anonymous Times employee: www.tellzell.com

body: Real estate tycoon Sam Zell takes the Tribune Co. private in a $8.2 billion deal. The deal saddled the company with an estimated $13 billion in debt. Zell vows a long-term interest in his investment and says he's not interested in selling off individual newspapers. Zell installs a new management team, including CEO Randy Michaels, made up largely of former radio executives. Shortly after acquiring the company, Zell embarks on a tour of newsrooms to tell his new employees candidly about his vision for their future. * Note: The video below includes language some might consider offensive *
title: Sam Zell buys Tribune Co.
caption: Immediately after buying the Tribune Company, real estate mogul Sam Zell embarked on a newsroom tour, where he spoke, sometimes quite heatedly, to newspaper staff about the company's future.

body: The Tribune Co. files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after the L.A. Times, Chicago Tribune and its baseball team, the Chicago Cubs, all struggle with debt and falling revenues. Many blame the Tribune Co.’s decision to file Chapter 11 on Sam Zell, who added $13 billion in additional debt. The process will take four years to resolve.
title: Tribune Co. files for bankrupcy

body: About 70 full time employees are let go, or 11 percent of the total newsroom staff. “We are all too familiar with this process," Editor Russ Stanton writes to his staff. "But over the past year in particular, we have come through each of these downsizings and continued to produce some of the highest-quality journalism in our industry.”
title: 70 newsroom staff positions cut

body: After 47 years, the L.A. Times and Washington Post end their joint news service. Washington Post embarks on a new, similar economics and politics news service with Bloomberg
title: LA Times- Washington Post news agency ends

body: The New York Times reports what it calls a "bankrupt" corporate culture at the Tribune Co., featuring interviews with many current and former Tribune employees. The culture, many allege, was ushered in by Zell's appointed chief, Randy Michaels. By the month's end, Michaels is forced to resign.
title: Questions raised about Tribune Co. management
caption: Randy Michaels, former CEO of the Tribune Company.

body: L.A. Times spokeswoman Nancy Sullivan blames the downturn in the economy. The number of news staffers reaches a low of around 600, down from 940 in April 2007, according to the newspaper.
title: More newsroom cuts

body: With daily readership dwindles to 572,998, almost half of what it was a decade earlier, Editor Russ Stanton leaves the Times. He becomes the third consecutive editor to leave under duress after objecting to proposed cuts to the newsroom staff. Stanton takes a job as KPCC's Vice President of News and is succeeded by Times' Managing Editor Davan Maharaj. (Stanton leaves KPCC in 2014.)
title: Editor Russ Stanton leaves. Circulation down by nearly half

body: Media mogul Rupert Murdoch is rumored to be interested in the L.A. Times and Tribune Co., sparking several stories and op-eds in local papers.
title: Murdoch is rumored to be interested in Times and Tribune
caption: Ruppert Murdoch, chairman and CEO of News Corporation, attends the e-G8 meeting gathering Internet and information technologies leaders and experts at the Tuileries gardens

body: After four years of Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, the Tribune Co. announces that it has emerged from bankruptcy. It says it plans to maintain ownership of its newspapers. "Tribune will emerge as a dynamic multimedia company with a great mix of profitable assets, powerful brands in major markets, sufficient liquidity for operations and investments and significantly less debt," Chief Executive Eddy Hartenstein says in a statement reported by Reuters.
title: Tribune, Times emerge from bankrupcy, hire new board

body: Billed as a "membership program," the L.A. Times begins charging for access to its online content. The price is 99 cents for the first 30 days of content, after which the price rises to $1.99 a week with a subscription to the L.A. Times Sunday edition.
title: Latimes.com begins charging for access

body: Billionaire former home builder and investment services magnate Eli Broad suggests he's interested in teaming up with others to buy the Times once it emerges from bankruptcy, when "the price should be better and the advantages of local ownership clear to all." Broad earlier lost out on his bid to accquire the Tribune Co. to Sam Zell. In later months, Broad announces that he and former L.A. Deputy Mayor Austin Beutner are teaming up to explore the possibility of purchasing the Times.
title: Billionaire philanthropist Eli Broad expresses interest
caption: Billionaire philanthropist Eli Broad

body: Conservative billionaire brothers David and Charles Koch are rumored to be interested in buying the Tribune Co. and the L.A. Times. A spokeswoman for the Kochs will later say they reconsidered a bid because such an investment would not be "economically viable."
title: Koch Brothers express interest in buying the Times

body: Another staff reduction is announced the same day that the Tribune Co. says its net income has fallen 41 percent from the previous year. The graphic and design team takes the hardest hit.
title: More layoffs: Graphics team bears brunt

body: The announcement comes after the Tribune Co. decided to add more TV stations to its portfolio and in an attempt to cut taxes. The Tribune will be split between Tribune Media and Tribune Publishing, which assumes ownership of the L.A. Times. "Moving to separate our publishing and broadcasting assets into two distinct companies will bring single-minded attention to the journalistic standards, advertising partnerships and digital prospects of our iconic newspapers, while also enabling us to take advantage of the operational and strategic opportunities created by the significant scale we are building in broadcasting," Tribune CEO Peter Liguori says, according to USA Today.
title: Tribune announces that it will split up the company
caption: A bicyclist passes photos displayed on the Los Angeles Times building after the Tribune Co. announced that it wants to split its broadcasting and publishing businesses into two companies on July 10, 2013 in Los Angeles, California.

body: The conservative billionaire Koch Brothers reconsider their bid to buy the L.A. Times, a bid they say is not “economically viable.”
title: Koch Brothers decide against buying the LA Times
caption: In this Aug. 30, 2013 file photo, Americans for Prosperity Foundation Chairman David Koch  speaks in Orlando, Fla.

body: The L.A. Times launches a redesign of its site, including a responsive design that conforms to the device it's being viewed on.  "Our mission was to raise the standard for digital news and create a site that truly engages users as stories break and build,” Times Editor Davan Maharaj says in a press release.
title: Latimes.com launches redesign

body: After much speculation, Murdoch says on Twitter that he cannot buy the Tribune Co. or the L.A. Times because he believes cross-ownership laws would prevent it.
mediaurl:
Sorry can't buy Trib group or LA Times - cross-ownership laws from another age still in place.

— Rupert Murdoch (@rupertmurdoch) July 18, 2014
title: Murdoch tweets he's unable to make bid

body: The Tribune Co. — renamed Tribune Media — spins off its newspapers in a new company called Tribune Publishing. Some analysts say that the spinoff company will be worth $635 million.
title: Tribune Co. spins off newspapers as new company
caption: Pedestrians walk near the Tribune Tower, headquarters of the Tribune Company on June 7, 2012 in Chicago, Illinois.
